conversation.content: [nervously] I saw the marquee outside with your name on it—'Lighting Design by Maya Chen'—and my heart just stopped because it's actually happening for you.
[very quietly] Alex?
[warmly] The security guard almost didn't let me backstage, but I told him we used to build blanket forts with Christmas lights in your parents' basement. [chuckles] He thought I was insane.
How did you even know about tonight? I haven't posted anything online, haven't told anyone from back home about this show.
Your mom called mine last week. [pause] She's been calling her every opening night for the past five years, apparently.
[bitter] Of course she has. [sighs] She still thinks if she tells enough people from the old neighborhood, somehow I'll magically appear back in that suburban kitchen.
[gently] That's not why I came, Maya. I came because fifteen years ago we promised we'd be there for each other's biggest moments, remember?
[defensive] We promised a lot of things before you disappeared to California without saying goodbye—just that stupid email about needing space to figure yourself out.
[regretful] I know.
[shaky voice] Do you have any idea how many opening nights I've had where I looked for you in the audience? [laughs bitterly] Even though I knew you wouldn't be there.
[very sincerely] I kept every review, Maya. Every single one. The Times piece about your innovative use of shadow in that Tennessee Williams revival? I read it twelve times.
[confused] You followed my career? All these years of radio silence and you were watching from three thousand miles away?
[empathetically] Moving to California wasn't about leaving you—it was about not dragging you into my mess. [exhales] My dad's bankruptcy, the drinking, everything was falling apart.
[softly] I would have helped you through it, Alex. That's what we did—we got each other through things.
[crying while speaking] You were getting into Yale Drama, and I was selling my guitar to help Mom pay rent. How could I tell you that?
[warmly] Because I would have sold mine too. [chuckles softly] Remember when we busked in Central Park that summer, saving up for those concert tickets?
[relieved] Twenty-three dollars in six hours.
[excited] And we thought we were rich! [laughs] God, we were so convinced we'd conquered New York with our terrible Bob Dylan covers.
[hopefully] I'm here now.
[very sincerely] I have to run final light checks in ten minutes, but after the show—after the party—we could get terrible diner coffee at three AM? [pause] Like we used to?

scenario: After fifteen years apart, a childhood friend surprises their estranged best friend who's become a successful Broadway lighting designer on opening night.
